entry.title: SAP DM ST2300 - Use of ESEF transformation registry version 5
entry.content:
Hi Marc_Kuipers,

I have a question regarding one guidelin from ESEF Reporting Manual Preparation of Annual Financial Reports in ESEF format (Update October 2025).

Guidance 2.2.3 Transformation of facts [last updated: October 2025] Whenever a string or numeric text used in an issuerâ€™s report does not follow the format based on the predefined data type of taxonomy element used to mark up such string or numeric text, a transformation rule shall be applied.

For that purpose, ESMA recommends applying the Transformation Rules Registry 5, as published by XBRL International on the dedicated website or any more recent versions of the Transformation Rules Registry provided with a â€˜Recommendationâ€™ status at XBRL International.

Question: When will the Registry 5 selection option be available in SAP DM?

â€˜https://www.xbrl.org/Specification/inlineXBRL-transformationRegistry/REC-2022-02-16/inlineXBRL-transformationRegistry-REC-2022-02-16.html

The manual indicates that the use of Registry 4 is still correct.

However, the customer expects information on this subject.

We are working on version ST2300.

Regards,

Iwona

entry.title: Material Ledger handling for Group Valuation (4G) when not used functionally - S/4HANA Cloud, Public
entry.content:
Dear Community,

We are reviewing how Material Ledger should be handled when Group Valuation (5W2) is technically active but not required from a business or reporting perspective.

We are aware that Group Valuation cannot be technically deactivated once it is activated.
However, we would like to clarify the behavior specifically from a Material Ledger perspective.

In the current system, Group Valuation will not be used from a business or reporting perspective. There is only one company code in the system, and no group-level valuation is required.

Our question is:
Is there any configuration or recommended approach in Material Ledger to avoid operational processing for the 4G (Group Valuation) ledger, even though Group Valuation remains technically active?

More specifically:

  • Can the Material Ledger be configured so that 4G does not require an actual costing run (CKMLCP) in each period?

  • If CKMLCP must technically run for all ML valuation views, is there a way to execute it in a minimal or neutral way for 4G (for example, without price differences or business impact)?

We are looking for best practices to minimize period-end effort related to Group Valuation when it is not used functionally.

BR,
Evrim

entry.title: SideEffect is not refreshing the criticality icon after bound action call
entry.content:
TL;DR: After the bound action changeStatus, Fiori Elements refreshes status_code (value and text), but the criticality icon doesnâ€™t update because it comes from the navigation property status.criticality, which isnâ€™t covered by the declared SideEffects. A full page refresh reloads the icon correctly.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Iâ€™m using SAP CAP (Node.js) with Fiori Elements (OData V4). I have a Books entity with a status association to BookStatus. 

entity Books : cuid, managed {
    status : Association to BookStatus;
}

 BookStatus contains a criticality integer which drives the criticality icon in FE.

entity BookStatus {
    key code        : String(1) enum {
            Available = 'A';
            Low_Stock = 'L';
            Unavailable = 'U';
        }
        criticality : Integer;
        displayText : String;
}

 After executing a bound action changeStatus, the UI refreshes status_code, the display text but the criticality icon does not change:

Here is the action with the side effect.

entity Books as projection on db.Books
    actions {
            @(Common.SideEffects: {TargetProperties: ['status_code']})
            action changeStatus(newStatus: String);
        };

Here is the action logic:

    this.on('changeStatus', Books, async (req) => {
      const bookId = req.params[0].ID
      const newStatus = req.data.newStatus
      await UPDATE(Books)
        .set({ status_code: newStatus })
        .where({ ID: bookId })
    })

Field annotated as follows:

{
 $Type : 'UI.DataField',
 Value : status_code,
 Criticality : status.criticality,
}

Here the data used for my BookStatus entity:

codecriticalitydisplayText
A3Available
L2Low Stock
U1Unavailable

And the thing is that after refreshing the page, the icon is reloaded correctly. So that is just the side effect issue.
And here is the github repo, if anyone wants to reproduce this issue:
Frontmaniaac/Bookstore-CAP-Tutorial
I know that it should work. Based on:
SAP-samples/fiori-elements-feature-showcase
But I cannot figure it out in my project.

entry.title: Re: Program Settings: Apply Gates and Accelerators
entry.content:
Curves are used more often than gates or accelerators, however, the curves have and end point, which limits their functionality.   The gates are used to ensure a minimum performance level to receive a bonus. Again, you can accomplish this via the curve as well.  This will save the company money on bonuses where they don't pay out for performance that does not meet a standard.  Accelerators are also not commonly used but can be more flexible than the curve in that there does not have to be as many data points and you can leave it more open ended unless you couple it with a cap.  

In my experience, curves are used more often than gates and accelerators

entry.title: How to test Cloud Hotfolder locally in SAP Commerce Cloud
entry.content:
Introduction

This article describes how to test Cloud Hotfolder locally in order to facilitate integration and customisation.

By default SAP Commerce Cloud zip file doesn't embed Cloud Hotfolder extensions. Those extensions can be found in this following KBA note : https://me.sap.com/notes/2817992

Three extensions should be installed:

  • azurecloudhotfolder
  • cloudcommons
  • cloudhotfolder

Prerequisites

First thing is to install Azurite which will simulate azure blob storage in local filesystem

$ npm install -g azurite

Then we can start the service

$ azurite -l /tmp
Azurite, Version 2.7.0
A lightweight server clone of Azure Storage

Azure Table Storage Emulator listening on port 10002
Azure Queue Storage Emulator listening on port 10001
Azure Blob Storage Emulator listening on port 10000

 Now we should install Microsoft Azure Storage Explorer: https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/features/storage-explorer/

Open Microsoft Azure Storage Explorer and attach the local blob storage

Installation

Download latest SAP Commerce Cloud 2211 patched version from https://me.sap.com/softwarecenter

Unzip SAP Commerce Cloud 

Install electronics B2C accelerator 

Download Cloud Hotfolder extensions (pickup suitable version) : https://me.sap.com/notes/2817992

Install those extensions in hybris/bin/custom folder

Add this following extension in localextensions.xml

<extension name='azurecloudhotfolder' />

Add this following settings in local.properties

# Azure Blob Store: Remote (SandBox D1)
#azure.hotfolder.storage.account.connection-string=DefaultEndpointsProtocol=https;AccountName=...;AccountKey=...
#azure.hotfolder.storage.account.name=...

# Azure Blob Store: Local (Azurite or CCv2 env)
azure.hotfolder.storage.account.connection-string=UseDevelopmentStorage=true
# azure.hotfolder.storage.account.name=devstoreaccount1

# general setting
cluster.node.groups=integration,yHotfolderCandidate
azure.hotfolder.storage.container.hotfolder=master/hotfolder

# debug
log4j2.logger.azure.name = de.hybris.platform.cloud.azure.hotfolder
log4j2.logger.azure.level = DEBUG
log4j2.logger.azure.appenderRef.stdout.ref = STDOUT

log4j2.logger.cloud.name = de.hybris.platform.cloud.hotfolder
log4j2.logger.cloud.level = DEBUG
log4j2.logger.cloud.appenderRef.stdout.ref = STDOUT

log4j2.logger.cloud.name = de.hybris.platform.cloud.commons
log4j2.logger.cloud.level = DEBUG
log4j2.logger.cloud.appenderRef.stdout.ref = STDOUT

Compile and Init the platform

Start the platform, we should see this output every 6s

DEBUG [HybrisIntegrationTaskExecutorThread1] [AzureBlobSession] Listing contents of container [hybris] on path [master/hotfolder].
DEBUG [HybrisIntegrationTaskExecutorThread1] [AzureBlobInboundSynchronizer] 0 files transferred

Testing

To test data import, we can use this following zip file template : product-with-media-001.zip

product.csv

112233,,Test Product 2,Test Product 2 Description,ean,manufacturer,manufacturerAID,pieces,approved,jp-vat-full,

raw.impex

$defaultPassword=1234
$setName=name[cellDecorator=de.hybris.platform.acceleratorservices.dataimport.batch.decorator.CustomerNameDecorator]

INSERT_UPDATE Customer;uid[unique=true];$setName;title(code);password[default=$defaultPassword]
;raw.impex@domain.com;Raw Impex;mr

zip_media.csv

112233,y_logo.png

 Push this file into hybris container into folder master/hotfolder

Then we should have this log trace

DEBUG [HybrisIntegrationTaskExecutorThread1] [BlobTransferredAspect] about to run method [read] on target [de.hybris.platform.cloud.azure.hotfolder.remote.session.AzureBlobSession@394dd2a9] with path [master/hotfolder/product-with-media-001.zip]
DEBUG [HybrisIntegrationTaskExecutorThread1] [AzureBlobSession] Reading from container [hybris] on path [master/hotfolder/product-with-media-001.zip].
INFO  [HybrisIntegrationTaskExecutorThread1] [LoggingMonitorRecorder] HOT_FOLDER:product-with-media-001.zip1544632066000 Status [IN_PROGRESS]
Step [DOWNLOADED] Node [0] Status [SUCCESS] Started [2018-12-12T17:28:29.344+01:00] Ended [2018-12-12T17:28:29.378+01:00] Duration [34]ms Message [Successfully read blob [master/hotfolder/product-with-media-001.zip] of size [247 KB]] Actions [none]
WARN  [HybrisIntegrationTaskExecutorThread1] [BlobTransferredAspect] No MonitorHistory within the thread, cannot add successful Step [DOWNLOADED] started [2018-12-12T17:28:29.341+0100]
WARN  [HybrisIntegrationTaskExecutorThread1] [BlobTransferredAspect] No MonitorHistory within the thread, cannot checkpoint
WARN  [HybrisIntegrationTaskExecutorThread1] [BlobTransferredAspect] No MonitorHistory within the thread, cannot add successful Step [DOWNLOADED] started [2018-12-12T17:28:29.338+0100]
WARN  [HybrisIntegrationTaskExecutorThread1] [BlobTransferredAspect] No MonitorHistory within the thread, cannot checkpoint
DEBUG [HybrisIntegrationTaskExecutorThread1] [AzureBlobSession] Removing from container [hybris] on path [master/hotfolder/product-with-media-001.zip].
DEBUG [HybrisIntegrationTaskExecutorThread1] [AzureBlobInboundSynchronizer] deleted remote file: master/hotfolder/product-with-media-001.zip
DEBUG [HybrisIntegrationTaskExecutorThread1] [AzureBlobInboundSynchronizer] 1 files transferred
DEBUG [HybrisIntegrationTaskExecutorThread1] [FileUnzippedAspect] about to run method [doTransform] on target [unZipTransformer]
DEBUG [HybrisIntegrationTaskExecutorThread1] [BatchHeaderAspect] about to run method [executeZip] on target [de.hybris.platform.cloud.hotfolder.dataimport.batch.zip.task.ZipHeaderInitTask@d9475a6]
DEBUG [HybrisIntegrationTaskExecutorThread1] [BatchHeaderAspect] about to run method [executeZip] on target [de.hybris.platform.cloud.hotfolder.dataimport.batch.zip.task.ZipHeaderTransformerTask@47445751]

From /backoffice, we should see the new product 112233 imported with his media in electronics staged catalog

entry.title: Email notifications not triggered for PR Flexible Workflow
entry.content:
We are using SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition and have configured Flexible Workflow for Purchase Requisition (PR) approval.

Issue Description:

The PR approval workflow is triggered correctly, and approver determination works as expected. Approvers receive approval tasks in My Inbox, and workflow processing functions normally. However, email notifications are not consistently triggered, and the Notification / Email tab is not visible in the Flexible Workflow configuration for Purchase Requisitions.

Expected System Behavior:

  1. When a PR is created and submitted for approval:
    • The approver should receive a workflow task in My Inbox.
    • The approver should also receive an email notification informing them of the pending approval.
  3. After the PR is approved or rejected:
    • The PR initiator should receive a system notification.
    • The PR initiator should also receive an email notification confirming the approval or rejection.

Actual System Behavior:

  • Workflow triggers correctly.
  • Approval task is created and visible in My Inbox.
  • Approver determination is correct.
  • Email notifications are not triggered.
  • Email tab is not available in the Flexible Workflow app for PRs.

Steps to Reproduce:

  1. Create a Purchase Requisition that meets the workflow start condition.
  2. Submit the PR.
  3. Workflow is triggered and approval task is created.
  4. Approver receives task in My Inbox.
  5. No email notification is received by the approver.
  6. After approval, no email notification is received by the PR initiator.

System Information:

  • Deployment: SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition
  • Application: Flexible Workflow for Purchase Requisitions
  • Fiori App: Manage Workflows for Purchase Requisitions

Request:

Kindly confirm:

  • Whether email notifications for PR Flexible Workflow are supported in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition.
  • Whether the absence of the Notification / Email tab in PR Flexible Workflow is standard system behavior.
  • If email notifications are supported, please advise the required configuration or prerequisites.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Email notifications not triggered for PR Flexible Wor...
entry.content:
Hello,

Kindly refer to KBA 3304179 - Email notification tab is missing for purchasing workflows.

It is first needed to create copies of the predelivered email templates so that the notification tab is shown and the email notification can be configured.

Also refer to the below SAP Help page for more information on the general configuration:

  • How to Configure the Flexible Workflow for Purchase Requisitions | SAP Help Portal

 

Best regards.

entry.title: Re: Proration based on month
entry.content:
Our standard functionality does not prorate based on months.   We do have the functionality to shift the start date of an assignment to the first of a month or an end date to the last day of the month.  This gets you closer but not exact because someone who starts on 7/1 should get 50% (6 of 12 months) but the days even if you adjust start dates or end dates, is not exactly 50%.   I am often successful in consulting the client the days are actually more precise and with adjusting start dates and end dates, we get really close.

If you need the actual number of months, you will have to use custom fields to determine the payout using custom fields and the formulas will vary based on the rules the client will follow.

entry.title: Using Common Activity Types in Professional Services and Service Management in S/4HANA Cloud Public
entry.content:
In S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition for Professional Services, there are 20 default T-activity types that are delivered out of the box by SAP. In some companies, it could be the case that these activity types are required to be used in both the lines of business professional service as well as service order management. In professional service, the association between activity types and the bill rates are automatically maintained using the billing profile configuration settings. Please refer to the following blog post by Tobias Schmidt for a deeper look into this topic.

In this blog post, I would like to demonstrate for the service management line-of-business, which configuration needs to be done to fulfill this requirement.

 

The scenario I would like to illustrate in this blog post is the business need, wherein common activity types are used between the lines of business professional services and service order management in S/4HANA Cloud. This is common in certain industries

  • Create/rename the activity types: In the app â€œManage Activity Typesâ€, rename the standard activity types T001 to T020 according to your business needs. The standard T- activity types can be renamed to correspond If needed, create further activity types beyond the 20 default activity types delivered out-of-the-box.

    •  

  • Create the cost rates: next, in the â€œManage Cost Rates â€“ Servicesâ€ app, maintain the individual cost rates for the different combinations of company code/cost center/activity type (and optionally Service Cost Level)

    •  

  • Create the service product master data: finally for the determination of the correct cost rates for the products used in the service orders, you will need to create separate product master data (with material type SERV and item category group SRVP), as the T-materials delivered out of the box can only be used in customer projects or internal projects due to the respective item category determination.

    •  

  • *Assign the activity types to service products: after creating the service products, you will need to assign these to the corresponding activity types in the configuration activity â€œAssign Activity Type to Service Productâ€ (SSCUI 102920). For the professional service projects, the assignment is done implicitly using the configuration activity â€œMaintain Billing Profileâ€ (SSCUI 103637)

    •  

 

With this setup, you can successfully use common activity types and cost rates and correctly determine them for the transactions in the different lines-of-business Professional Services and Service Management.

entry.title: Re: Partial GI & Splitting ODO in S/4 HANA Public Cloud E...
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community,

This feature is available in the Warehouse Monitor APP. You ca:

  • "Split Open Quantity into new ODO" on the node of outbound delivery order (ODO) items:
    You can select one or more items. Those items that have no warehouse task are split into a new ODO.
  • "Split into new ODO" on the handling unit (HU) node of ODOs:
    The selected HUs are split into a new ODO.

You can use those features to remove parts of an outbound delivery order that, for example, are not ready to be shipped or for which there is no space on the transport, by splitting those parts into a new outbound delivery order. You can split the outbound delivery order either before or after warehouse processing has started with created or confirmed warehouse tasks. Access this feature through the Warehouse Monitor. Two new functions are available in the Warehouse Monitor for the following nodes:

  • Outbound Delivery Order > Outbound Delivery Order Item > More Methods >  Split Open Qty into new ODO

  • Documents > Handling Unit >  More methods > Split into new ODO

Please check the documents below for your reference:

SAP Help Portal - Delivery Split for Outbound Delivery Order

Roadmap Items - Warehouse-driven split of the outbound delivery order 2408

Influence Request - Allow partial goods issue for outbound delivery + delivery-split

Please let us know if you have further questions!

Best regards,

SAP Support.

entry.title: Train Joule AI for SAP ECC: Step-by-Step Guide: How to Create a Joule Skill for SAP ECC
entry.content:
INTRODUCTION

SAP Joule is SAPâ€™s AI copilot that helps users perform business tasks using natural language. A Joule skill is a defined capability that allows Joule to answer questions or trigger actions in SAP systems.

SAP Joule is not natively built for direct integration with SAP ECC (Enterprise Core Component). It is primarily designed as a cloud native AI copilot for SAP's cloud solutions, such as SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP SuccessFactors.

However, customers on ECC can still leverage some of Joule's capabilities through hybrid approaches using the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).  This blog explains how to design and create a Joule skill that works with SAP ECC, using SAPâ€™s recommended tools and architecture.

Step 1: Understand What a Joule Skill Is

A Joule skill consists of:

  • A user intent (what the user asks Joule)
  • Business logic (what happens behind the scenes)
  • System integration (ECC in this case)
  • A structured response back to the user

Example:

â€œJoule, show me the open sales orders for top problematic customer ABC.â€

Step 2: Identify the Use Case in SAP ECC

Start with a simple, high value use case.

Good examples

  • Check sales order status of top 5 customers
  • Customer 360 degree snapshots
  • Display open invoices
  • Get material stock levels
  • Which orders are delayed today?
  • Which materials are at risk this week?
  • What is product costing for X product in last 5 years? Where am I spending more money?

Define clearly:

  • What data is needed from ECC
  • Which transaction or table provides it
  • Whether itâ€™s read only or triggers an action

Why itâ€™s great:

  • Sales + Finance or Procurement+Finance in one answer
  • Simple answers to today's painful questions
  • Very executive-friendly and great for planners without systems

Step 3: Prepare SAP ECC for Integration

Joule does not connect directly to ECC. You need an API layer.

Common integration options:

  • OData services (via SAP Gateway)
  • RFC / BAPI exposed through SAP Integration Suite
  • IDocs (less common for Joule)

Actions:

  1. Identify the ECC function module or BAPI
  2. Expose it as an OData service or API
  3. Test the API independently

Example:

  • BAPI_SALESORDER_GETSTATUS
  • BAPI_CUSTOMER_GETDETAIL

Step 4: Set Up SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP)

Joule skills are built and orchestrated on SAP BTP. You will need:

  • SAP BTP account
  • SAP Integration Suite
  • SAP Build Process Automation or Build Apps
  • SAP AI Core / AI Launchpad (if using advanced AI logic)

Ensure:

  • ECC is connected securely to BTP
  • Authentication (OAuth / Principal Propagation) is configured

Step 5: Create the Business Logic (Skill Backend)

Now you define what the skill actually does.

Options:

  • SAP Build Process Automation (recommended)
  • SAP Build Apps
  • CAP (Cloud Application Programming) model

Steps:

  1. Create a process or service
  2. Consume the ECC API
  3. Map input parameters (e.g., customer number)
  4. Format the output clearly for Joule

Example output:

  • Sales order number
  • Status
  • Delivery date

Step 6: Define the Joule Skill (Intent)

This is where Joule learns how users talk.

You define:

  • Skill name
  • User intent
  • Sample phrases

Examples:

  • â€œShow open sales orders for customer 10001â€
  • â€œWhat is the status of sales order 4500001234?â€
  • â€œCheck customer ABC ordersâ€

These help Joule understand variations in natural language.

Step 7: Connect Joule to the Backend Logic

Now connect:

  • The user intent
  • To the backend service or process

Actions:

  • Map extracted parameters (order number, customer ID)
  • Trigger the ECC API call
  • Capture the response
  • Return structured data to Joule

Step 8: Design the Response Experience

Joule responses should be:

  • Short
  • Clear
  • Actionable

Examples:

  • Text summary
  • Bullet points
  • Table Style

Bad response:

â€œHere is the data you requested.â€

Good response:

â€œCustomer ABC has 3 open sales orders. The next delivery is scheduled for 12 Oct.â€

Step 9: Test the Joule Skill

Testing is critical.

Test scenarios:

  • Valid and Invalid input
  • Missing parameters
  • Incorrect values
  • No data found
  • Performance delays

Test in:

  • SAP Joule preview
  • BTP logs
  • ECC backend logs

Step 10: Secure and Authorize the Skill

Ensure:

  • Only authorized users can access ECC data
  • Role based access is enforced
  • Sensitive fields are masked if needed

Use:

  • SAP Identity Authentication (IAS)
  • Role collections in BTP
  • ECC authorization objects

Step 11: Deploy and Enable for Users

Once tested:

  1. Deploy the backend service
  2. Activate the Joule skill
  3. Assign it to user roles
  4. Enable it in the SAP application where Joule is use

Step 12: Monitor and Improve

After go live:

  • Monitor usage
  • Review failed queries
  • Expand to new ECC use cases

Over time, Joule becomes smarter and more valuable.

Conclusion

Creating a Joule skill for SAP ECC involves:

  • Clear business use cases
  • API based ECC integration
  • SAP BTP orchestration
  • Well designed natural language interaction

While ECC is a legacy system, Joule allows it to be used in a modern, conversational way.

#SAP #Deloitte #AIinSAP #Joule #SAPECC #SAPJoule #SAPBTP #EnterpriseAI #AI #Interim

entry.title: Re: Unable to generate e-way bill through FNR No for Rake...
entry.content:
What is happening in your case is Error 4042: Invalid RR number is not an SAP error, but a NIC (Government Eâ€‘Way Bill portal) validation error. The NIC system has recently tightened validation rules for Railway Receipt (RR) / FNR numbers. Earlier, SAP allowed you to pass the 11â€‘digit FNR number directly in the FA Tracking No field of VT01N/VT02N, and NIC accepted it. In the last week, NIC has started rejecting numbers that donâ€™t match the expected RR number format. I believe, it is 10 digits, sometimes with prefix rules depending on railway zones.

Check NICâ€™s latest specification. RR number must be exactly 10 digits. No alphabetic characters, spaces, or prefixes allowed. If youâ€™re passing 11 digits, NIC will reject it.

In VT01N/VT02N, ensure the FA Tracking No field is populated with the correct 10â€‘digit RR number. If your FNR is 11 digits, confirm whether the first digit is a prefix that should be dropped.

For GST specific, lot of SAP notes are there and check in Service Marketplace for the latest update

entry.title: Re: How to calculate VOWD (Value of Work Delivered) in SA...
entry.content: SAP Project System does not provide a standard delivered report for VOWD (Value of Work Delivered). VOWD is a petroleum industryâ€“specific metric based on commitments (purchase orders, contracts, services received), whereas SAPâ€™s standard Earned Value (EV) reporting is based on planned values. To calculate VOWD in SAP PS, you typically need a custom development or reporting solution that reads commitments and actuals from PS/CO tables (e.g. EBAN, EKPO, CO commitments, PRCD_ELEMENTS) and applies VOWD rules. The SAP Help documentation on BCWP shared here, does not cover VOWD, because VOWD is not a standard SAP metric.

entry.title: Customer Returns Scrapping Process with WM storage locations in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
In this blog post, I would like to detail the customer returns process (Scope Item â€˜BKPâ€™) when it comes to customers that are using warehouse managed (WM) storage locations. As the official scope item test script and official documentation covers the process using simple inventory managed storage locations, I would like to use this blog post to showcase which additional steps occur due to a WM storage location being used. As a specific example for this blog post, Iâ€™ll be using the follow up activity 0012 (Scrapping) in the customer returns process to show the steps necessary as a result of using WM storage locations.

 

The process starts with the creation of a returns order (I will be using the advanced returns order with order type â€˜CBARâ€™) and subsequent returns delivery. During the creation of the returns order, choose the follow-up activity â€œReceive Into Plantâ€ (0001).

Now comes the first step, where these is a slightly different process than described in the test script due to the usage of a WM managed storage location. The returns delivery created in the first step will be distributed to the WMS system and therefore cannot be processed using the standard app. You will here need to use the WM specific app â€œChange Inbound Deliveries â€“ Deliveriesâ€:

 

Next, go into the delivery, post the goods receipt, and create the warehouse tasks, in this order.

 

After creating the warehouse tasks, go into them and confirm the picking:

 

 

Now that the returns delivery is processed, the next step is to continue with the material inspection in the warehouse (App: Enter Inspection Results â€“ From Warehouse). Here, select the returns delivery, maintain the inspection code, and select the follow-up activity 0012 Scrapping, before saving and confirming the inspection:

 

Upon this, a new outbound delivery will be created in the returns overview, which is the basis for the scrapping. Now, two further important steps come into play, which also need to be executed additionally due to WM storage locations in place.

In the app â€œProcess Posting Change Itemâ€, select the appropriate warehouse number and execute. For the outbound delivery item in question, select the item and create a WT in the background:

 

Next, double-click on the line, which will open up the created warehouse task in the screen half below. Select the Warehouse task and confirm the WT in the background:

 

As a final step after this, you will need to use another specific app for this process variant, which is the app â€œPost Goods Issue â€“ Unplannedâ€. Here as well, enter the warehouse number, select the GI process â€œscrappingâ€, and select Run:

 

After this, select the line, and execute Post GI. This finally posts the goods issue for scrapping, and the returned material is removed from the inventory of the plant.

 

With this, the main part of the customer returns process is complete, and the user simply needs to parallelly proceed with the refund control steps (credit memo or replacement delivery). To summarize, when it comes to using WM managed storage locations in this process for the scrapping scenario, the additional apps need to be used on WM side are â€œChange Inbound Deliveries â€“ Deliveriesâ€, â€œProcess Posting Change Itemâ€, and â€œPost Goods Issue â€“ Unplannedâ€.

entry.title: OData Service of Business Partner in SAP S/4HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Introduction

This blog provides a complete walkthrough on enabling the API_BUSINESS_PARTNER OData service for maintaining Business Partner data in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, covering both Public Edition and Private Edition. The blog consolidates prerequisites, activation steps, and troubleshooting information into a single reference for technical consultants and integration teams.

API_BUSINESS_PARTNER

The API_BUSINESS_PARTNER OData service enables CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations on supported Business Partner entities, making it a core interface for inbound integration scenarios. This API is intended exclusively for CRUD operations, and it cannot be used for data replication purposes. For further information about API_BUSINESS_PARTNER, you can refer to the SAP Help Portal for S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and Private Edition.

Prerequisites

Before enabling the service, ensure that the system has at least one active Communication Arrangement for the communication scenario SAP_COM_0008.

Note: You do not need an existing SOAP replication service to enable or use this OData service.

If the scenario has not been configured yet, you can follow these steps â€“

  1. Create a communication user by following this link.
  2. Assign the communication user as your current S/4 systemâ€™s inbound communication user
    1. Open the Communication Systems app
    2. Click the Own SAP Cloud System button
    3. Choose Edit. Make a note of the System ID value, as it will be required for step 3.
    4. Under the Users for Inbound Communication tab, click the plus button to add a new user.
    5. Select the authentication method chosen for the user created in step 1.
    6. Enter the ID of the user created in step 1.
    7. Click the OK button.
    8. Save your changes. This will also be the user ID to authenticate the OData service.
  3. Create a new Communication Arrangement.
    1. Open the Communication Arrangements app.
    2. Click on the New button.
    3. Enter SAP_COM_0008 as the Scenario, and provide a concise, identifiable Arrangement Name.
    4. Under the Common Data tab, choose the current SAP Cloud system (noted down in step 2) as the Communication System.
    5. Under the Inbound Communication tab, choose the User Name as the user assigned to the current SAP System as per step 2.
    6. Deactivate all the services under the Outbound Services tab by unchecking the Service Status checkbox for each service.
    7. Save your changes.

Enabling the Service in Public Cloud

In S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the OData service for API_BUSINESS_PARTNER is activated automatically as soon as the communication arrangement for SAP_COM_0008 is created.

Locating the OData Endpoint

  1. Open the Communication Arrangements app.
  2. Select the relevant communication arrangement.
  3. Navigate to the Inbound Services tab.
  4. Locate the entry Business Partner (A2X) â€” the Service URL displayed here is your API endpoint.

Using the Endpoint

This URL can be consumed through:

  • Any third-party API testing tool
  • SAP API Sandbox
  • REST clients used in your existing landscape

Enabling the Service in Private Cloud

For S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, some additional manual checks are required to activate and validate the service.

1. Register or Verify the OData Service

Follow these steps to ensure that API_BUSINESS_PARTNER is available in the SAP Gateway:

  1. Open Transaction: /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE (Service Catalog).

  2. In the External Service Name filter, search for: API_BUSINESS_PARTNER
    • If found â†’ continue to Step 6
    • If not â†’ proceed to next step


  3. Click Add Service.


  4. Search again using External Service Name: API_BUSINESS_PARTNER and System Alias: LOCAL. If System Alias LOCAL doesnâ€™t exist in the list of SAP System Aliases, press the button Add System Alias and add the value LOCAL.


  5. Add the service via the standard provisioning steps.

  6. Check if the ICF Node associated with the service is active in the Service Catalog (green traffic light). If not active, select the node â†’ ICF Node dropdown menu â†’ Activate. The service should now be active.

We can proceed to test our activated OData service.

Tip: If the system shows the message â€œSAP System Message: User no longer logged onâ€ when launching a /IWFND transaction, prefix it with /n.

Example: /n/IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE

2. Test the Service

The service can be validated using the SAP Gateway Client:

  • Via the SAP Gateway Client button within the Service Catalog, or
  • Transaction: /IWFND/GW_CLIENT

 

Troubleshooting

Issue: Service Active but Not Usable (Private Cloud)

Even after registering and activating the service, you may encounter access issues.

Solution:

In the Service Catalog entry for API_BUSINESS_PARTNER, ensure that the SAP System Alias is set to: LOCAL

 

Conclusion

Once you have successfully completed the setup steps outlined above for your respective S/4HANA Cloud edition, the API_BUSINESS_PARTNER OData service will be ready for integration into your landscape. For a comprehensive list of all supported entities and CRUD operations, refer to the SAP Business Accelerator for S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and Private Edition.

entry.title: End to End Buyer and Supplier flow visualization in ERP systems
entry.content:
Dear Community, 

in this short blog post, I would like to share my insights over the last years on how I've personally come to understanding the intertwined perspectives and bidirectional data-flow between ERP systems. From the sales perspective, you have the standard document flow of the Quote-to-Cash process such as Sales Quotation, Sales Order, Outbound Delivery, Goods Issue, and Customer Invoice. The similar document flow goes for the Procure-to-Pay process involving Purchasing Requisition, Purchase Order, Supplier Confirmation, Inbound Delivery, Goods Receipt, and Supplier Invoice. I've decided to just put together a combined data flow which represents the document from one of the perspectives (seller) , and what this corresponds to from the perspective of the recipient (buyer) of the document. Hope this helps some of you in better understanding both sides of the coin ğŸ™‚

entry.title: Re: Help on RA Costs on GR55
entry.content:
To answer your question "Where the RA Value Comes From (CJE0)", the figure you see (572,601.05) is calculated by the RA key assigned to the WBS element/network. RA derives values from:

  • Planned costs (from PS/CO planning)
  • Actual costs (from CO postings)
  • Commitments (POs, PRs)
  • Revenue recognition rules (depending on RA method: cost-based, revenue-based, percentage of completion, etc.)

These values are stored in RA tables (e.g. COSB, COEP, COEJ, and summarized into COSP/COSS). So the number in CJE0 is not a â€œpostedâ€ cost, but a calculated RA value.

Why it doesnâ€™t appear in GR55 is because, GR55 reports are based on Report Painter/Writer definitions, usually pulling from FI/CO totals tables (COSP, COSS, GL accounts). By default, GR55 shows posted actuals and plan values, not RA calculated values. RA values are valuation results, not automatically transferred into FI/CO totals unless you run settlement or RA transfer to FI. If RA results are not settled or transferred, GR55 will show â€œno cost recordedâ€ because it only sees posted costs.

Ensure RA results are transferred to FI/CO (via transaction KKA2/KKA3 or settlement). Without transfer, GR55 wonâ€™t pick them up.

If you want RA values in GR55, you need to extend the report to include RA line items (from COSB/COEP). Standard GR55 does not include RA valuation results.

For RA values, SAP recommends CJE0/CJEN or RA line item reports. GR55 is not intended to show RA valuation unless customized.

entry.title: Re: Custom Reusable elements and Custom Business Objects.
entry.content:
Good day @AngelT 

Thank you for your question

To summarise, you are not missing a hidden switch or something. The scenario you see is expected in public cloud.

1. Regarding Reusable Elements not appearing in the Code List based on CDS View, it is important you note that a Custom Code List created in Custom Reusable Elements is not a CDS view. Therefore, what you expect will never appear in the field type Code List based on CDS View because that value help expects a CDS View that fulfills specific requirements. See: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/46632054fa9d49a18b452ee287173aba.html?locale=en-US

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/acb2907f362944a5a9e1b5eb86e769dc.html?locale=en-US for more details.

I suggest you instead use field type Code List (not â€œbased on CDS Viewâ€) and select your published Custom Code List.

To answer your question regarding Manage Master Data app, you do not enable reusable element directly in Manage Master Data. You should rather enable a custom field for that app UI. See references Before Getting Started with Custom Fields and Creating Custom Fields for further insights.

 

2. Regarding your point/question on Custom Business Objects not appearing in Code List based on CDS View, note that CBO is also not a CDS view, so it will not show up in the value help view list for Code List based on CDS view. See Creating a Field of the Type Code List Based on CDS View and Custom Business Objects for more insights.

I suggest you use a custom field type Association to Business Objects and build the value help through Custom CDS View as described here: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_MARKETING_CLOUD/e0cd7c1ecf3d4f2f9feb46ec1c5b68fb/93f6abd65d754b38b259ca6ae23f69e9.html?locale=en-US

If you really need a Code List based on CDS View, then create a Custom CDS View that reads the CBO data and use that Custom CDS View as the value help view. See KBA 3124156 for some issues that may arise when you consider this option.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Delta issue in STIP Payout % in Variable Pay
entry.content:
@RituSingh12 

First of all you need to provide more screenshots because it's really hard to help without actually seeing the actual field you are talking about. For you STIP Target % makes sense but every customer calls this differently.

Now I think the issue here is what @DavidSomelofske suggested (issue with number of decimals on one of the format) except you need to add the decimals NOT To the format tied to the STIP Target % field but to the AMOUNT fields used to determine that %. 

Variable Pay uses amounts to derive % at almost every single level except the business goal itself if you use Direct Percent as payout metric.

Here is my advise: create a copy of your template. In the duplicated template, make ALL number formats end with .########### then run bonus calculation and launch worksheets and check whether the issue is fixed. If fixed, then revert number formats of the amount fields until you find the one that needs the extra decimals.

If still not fixed then you might need to add a custom format to your basis fied directly in the succession data model like this:

 

 

I'm pretty sure I've replied to this exact issue on a different thread in the past on this community......

 

Best,

Xavier

Dear @aniruddhab,

In Public Cloud there is no generic standard Excel uploader app for mass creation of Purchase Requisitions like a simple file-upload template. SAP even note that there is no suitable Migration Cockpit object mass-change option for PR bulk creation in Public Cloud

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3411702

IMPORTANT. If you are running Central Procurement / Central Purchasing as a hub there is the standard Fiori app Schedule Import of Purchasing Documents which can import purchase requisitions from connected systems

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0e602d466b99490187fcbb30d1dc897c/5853c320b10a49228c1ca8bde17e3802.html

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F3268')/S35

For building your own PR uploader, SAP provides a public API (recommended for Public Cloud)

API name: API_PURCHASEREQUISITION_2
This is the OData V4 Purchase Requisition API and is the recommended successor. SAP Help also shows the typical OData V4 service pattern for this API (host-dependent)

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/bb9f1469daf04bd894ab2167f8132a1a/43c43f584eff2160e10000000a44147b.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/bb9f1469daf04bd894ab2167f8132a1a/dad2402e2ff543e7971d788bf35b12c1.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/bb9f1469daf04bd894ab2167f8132a1a/de371314a0fc46e5a54b0c1cdd0d8ce4.html

https://api.sap.com/api/CE_PURCHASEREQUISITION_0001/overview

IMPORTANT. Older API (deprecated)

Recommendation for your PR uploader:

  • Build a small service/app (SAP BTP Integration Suite) that:

1. reads Excel/CSV

2. validates data

3. calls API_PURCHASEREQUISITION_2 to create PRs in bulk

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Which SAP IAS tenant should be used for SAP BTP when...
entry.content:
Dear @oquijano0327,

Answers for questions below:

 

If youâ€™re implementing Joule against non-production:

  • Connect the BTP subaccount used for that Joule setup to IAS Test if your system non-prod tenant is using IAS Test
  • That keeps the end-to-end chain consistent for that environment

If youâ€™re implementing Joule for production:

  • Connect the production Joule BTP subaccount to IAS Productive because production system should authenticate against that IAS tenant

More details below in PDF (Integrating Joule with SAP Solutions):

https://help.sap.com/doc/de3af3c0f81642dbaa4d36172ed57a72/CLOUD/en-US/79bfc83ab386450c8cd9c7937ce26a3a.pdf

Answers for questions below:

 

SAP best practices for Joule guide explicitly recommends operating each independent entity from its own dedicated SAP BTP subaccount, aligned to a single IAS tenant

Typical landscape pattern:

  • BTP subaccount (DEV/TEST Joule): Trust to IAS Test, integrates system non-prod and Work Zone used for Joule in that landscape
  • BTP subaccount (PROD Joule): Trust to IAS Productive, integrates system production

This also fits how IAS tenants are meant to structure landscapes: SAP notes that test vs productive tenants are technically the same the tenant type is mainly landscape structuring

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/tenant-model-and-licensing

Why this is usually the cleanest approach:

  • No cross-environment identity coupling
  • Clear separation of administrator changes, troubleshooting and audits
  • Avoids accidental user access from productive identities into non-prod apps or vice versa

IMPORTANT. The Global User ID is owned by IAS and is tenant-specific, so if you use IAS Test and IAS Productive the same person will typically have different Global User IDs in each environment which is fine as long as you treat them as separate Joule landscapes. It becomes a problem only if you try to mix systems from different IAS tenants into one Joule formation, which SAP explicitly warns against

Public Cloud + Joule specifics to watch:

  • OIDC trust in BTP to IAS (not SAML)
  • Same IAS domain across the integrated chain
  • Identity Provisioning (IPS) is typically needed especially because Joule uses SAP Build Work Zone for navigation scenarios and role-based access
  • Donâ€™t try to integrate multiple system tenants of the same product into one Joule formation use separate subscriptions/subaccounts if you must

Summary:

  • Integrating Joule with SAP Solutions (Guide PDF) prerequisites trust to IAS, constraints and the single IAS / single product-tenant per formation rules
  • Global User ID in integration scenarios (Cloud Identity) explains tenant-specific ownership of the Global User ID
  • SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant model / tenant types clarifies test vs productive are functionally the same and mainly landscape structuring
  • BTP trust to Identity Authentication

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity/system-integration-guide/global-user-id-in-integration-scenarios

https://help.sap.com/doc/de3af3c0f81642dbaa4d36172ed57a72/CLOUD/en-US/79bfc83ab386450c8cd9c7937ce26a3a.pdf

https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/tenant-types

https://help.sap.com/docs/btp/sap-business-technology-platform/managing-trust-from-sap-btp-to-identity-authentication-tenant?version=Cloud

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Documenting Decisions and Exceptions in SAP Business Workflow Using OneNote
entry.content:
SAP Business Workflow provides powerful capabilities to model, execute, and monitor business processes across the SAP system landscape. Tasks, events, roles, and error reactions can be defined in a structured and repeatable way, making workflows especially valuable for approval processes and exception handling scenarios.

However, while SAP Business Workflow describes what happens and when, it often does not capture why certain decisions were made or how specific exceptions were intentionally handled. This contextual knowledge is usually created outside the system and can be difficult to retrieve later.

This post describes a lightweight approach to documenting SAP Business Workflow decisions and exceptions using Microsoft OneNote as a complementary tool.

What SAP Business Workflow Covers â€“ and What It Doesnâ€™t

SAP Business Workflow excels at orchestrating business processes:

  • triggering workflows based on events
  • routing tasks to responsible roles or positions
  • reacting to errors and exceptional situations
  • supporting repeatable and auditable process execution

What it does not reliably capture is the surrounding context:

  • why a certain approval rule was chosen
  • which alternatives were discussed and rejected
  • why a standard workflow was adjusted
  • which exceptions are intentionally tolerated

This information is often discussed during workshops, design sessions, or incident resolution meetings and then disappears into emails or personal notes.

Typical Workflow Knowledge That Gets Lost

In real SAP projects, workflow-related knowledge is created continuously, for example:

  • business assumptions behind approval steps
  • escalation logic agreed with stakeholders
  • decisions made to handle error-triggered workflows
  • reasons for deviating from standard SAP workflows
  • lessons learned after workflow failures

While none of this information is strictly required to run a workflow, it becomes highly relevant months or years later when workflows are reviewed, extended, or questioned.

Using OneNote as a Lightweight Companion

OneNote is not part of SAP Business Workflow, and it should not replace system documentation or configuration tools. Its value lies in capturing contextual knowledge quickly and close to the source. In practice, I have found that capturing these decisions immediately after discussions is far more effective than documenting them later.

In practice, OneNote can be used to:

  • document decisions directly during workflow design discussions
  • capture rationale while it is still fresh
  • collect screenshots or references without interrupting SAP work
  • keep workflow-related notes searchable over time

Because OneNote is flexible and lightweight, it supports documentation â€œin the momentâ€ instead of postponing it to formal documents that are often never completed.

Example: Documenting a Workflow Exception

The example below illustrates how workflow-related context, decisions, and follow-up actions can be captured in a lightweight way without duplicating technical workflow configuration.

Why This Matters in an AI Context

As AI-assisted tools become more common in enterprise environments, the quality of underlying information becomes increasingly important.
AI systems rely on structured, contextual input to summarize, search, or analyze knowledge effectively.

While this approach does not focus on a specific AI solution, consistently documented workflow decisions and exceptions:

  • are easier to summarize automatically
  • can be searched semantically
  • can be reused across projects and teams

In this sense, lightweight documentation prepares SAP Business Workflow knowledge for future AI-assisted analysis without introducing additional complexity today.

Limitations and Considerations

This approach has clear boundaries:

  • it does not replace workflow configuration or monitoring tools
  • it is not official project documentation
  • sensitive or customer-specific data must be handled carefully

OneNote works best as a personal or small-team knowledge base that complements SAP Business Workflow rather than competing with it.

Conclusion

SAP Business Workflow is highly effective at executing business processes, but long-term understanding depends on capturing the context behind decisions and exceptions. By using a simple tool like Microsoft OneNote to document this information, workflow-related knowledge can be preserved in a practical and accessible way.

Over time, this helps maintain clarity, supports future changes, and improves confidence in how SAP Business Workflow solutions were designed and why they work the way they do.

entry.title: Discoveryâ€‘First AI Assessment for SAP Landscapes, An Essay
entry.content:
Artificial Intelligence in SAP environments has shifted from being an â€œexternal acceleratorâ€ to becoming an embedded capability across the SAP portfolio : especially in S/4HANA-centric landscapes and SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP).  In parallel, SAPâ€™s AI operating model has matured through services and patterns such as SAP AI Core (runtime/orchestration), SAP AI Launchpad (central lifecycle management), the unified AI API, and Joule as the conversational copilot experience across SAP applications.  Yet, many SAP AI initiatives still stall after pilots because teams start by debating â€œhow to implementâ€ rather than validating â€œwhat is worth implementingâ€ and â€œwhere AI is actually valuable and feasibleâ€ in the enterprise process fabric.

A disciplined way to avoid this trap is a discoveryâ€‘first AI assessment - a structured approach that stays implementationâ€‘agnostic while still being technologyâ€‘aware, so outcomes remain valid regardless of later platform or deployment decisions.  This essay reframes a sixâ€‘step approach for SAP AI discovery into a technical, architect-friendly method. It also overlays SAP guidance and best-practice assets (Discovery Center, AI BTP Best Practices, AI Core/Launchpad, Joule, and RAG patterns with SAP HANA Cloud Vector Engine) to ensure the assessment aligns with SAPâ€™s recommended adoption pathways.

This essay is based on the framework introduced on the original SAP Community article: 6 Steps to an AI Assessment in SAP: Discoveryâ€‘First Approach 

 

Fig:  6 Steps to an AI Assessment in SAP: Discovery-First Approach

Step 1: Frame the Assessment Scope

Define the Assessment Boundary in an S/4HANAâ€‘Centric System Context

Every AI assessment must begin with scope governance: identify the SAP domains (Finance, Supply Chain, Manufacturing, Sales, Asset Management, HCM, etc.), the adjacent applications, and the integration boundaries that matter - without drifting into build-versus-buy or tool comparisons.  In SAP programs, a reliable scoping abstraction is the business capability map or value-stream decomposition because it remains stable even when the underlying SAP configuration varies.

This discovery discipline mirrors the intent of SAPâ€™s Discover phase practices - where structured discovery is separated from delivery execution - similar in spirit to the Digital Discovery Assessment (DDA) concept that captures scope and integration needs before implementation handover.  The key is to frame the AI assessment as a portfolio discovery exercise, not an architecture design workshop.

Typical Discovery outputs :

  • Capability/value-stream boundary document (whatâ€™s in/out)
  • Stakeholder map and process ownership inventory (who â€œownsâ€ outcomes)

 

Step 2: Map Capabilities to Processes

Map Business Capabilities to S/4HANA Process Realization

AI opportunities in SAP do not originate from modules or transactions; they emerge where a business capability is operationalized through an endâ€‘toâ€‘end process and its associated decision points, exceptions, and data flows.  The technical architectâ€™s job in discovery is to translate capability language (eg., â€œForecastâ€‘toâ€‘Stockâ€, â€œHireâ€‘toâ€‘Retireâ€) into S/4HANA process realizations (document flows, validations, approvals, master/transactional data dependencies).

This mapping also surfaces the â€œshadow stepsâ€ around SAP - manual spreadsheets, offline reconciliations, or email-based approvals - that frequently indicate automation or augmentation potential.  Importantly, the mapping step sets up a repeatable method: once you anchor AI discovery in processes, you can evaluate opportunities consistently across multiple LoBs.

Typical Discovery outputs :

  • Capability process decomposition tree
  • Process pain-point register (manual effort, exception hotspots, latency)

Fig: Business Capability Map Model from LeanIX

Fig: Representation of End-to-End Planning Process Decomposition 

 

Step 3: Identify AI Opportunity Areas

Apply SAPâ€‘Relevant Heuristics to Identify AI Useâ€‘Case Candidates

With process decomposition in place, candidate use cases can be detected using heuristics that align with SAPâ€™s common AI scenario types:

  1. High manual effort / repetitive validations : intelligent automation opportunities (e.g., checks, approvals, triage).
  2. High exception rates : anomaly detection, recommendation, or guided resolution.
  3. Decision-intensive planning : predictive/optimization scenarios (forecasting, risk scoring, demand signals).
  4. Classification-heavy work (documents, tickets, master data enrichment) : ML classification/extraction candidates.
  5. Conversational access needs : natural language interfaces over SAP process data and knowledge.

A key technical nuance: discovery should consider evidence sources - historical transactional data, exception logs, process mining signals, and operational telemetry-to quantify where work concentrates and where variance is high. This prevents â€œidea-basedâ€ AI and anchors the pipeline in measurable process reality.

Typical Discovery outputs :

  1. Useâ€‘case hypothesis cards (problem, trigger, decision, data anchors, KPI)
  2. Candidate taxonomy (predictive vs classification vs GenAI assistant vs automation)

Step 4: Score Opportunities (Qualitative)

Qualitatively Score Value, Feasibility, and Adoption Readiness (Lightweight, Not a Full Business Case)

Discovery must prioritize, but it should do so with qualitative scoring rather than prematurely engineering a full ROI model.  The practical approach is to score each candidate along three vectors:

  1. Business value (cycle time reduction, compliance uplift, cost, working capital impact).
  2. Feasibility (data availability in S/4HANA, integration complexity, process standardization, automation baseline).
  3. Adoption readiness (change impact, user trust, ownership clarity, operating model maturity).

In SAP programs, the feasibility discussion is still â€œdiscovery-grade,â€ but it can be informed by SAP adoption assets : such as SAP Discovery Centerâ€™s Discover >> Evaluate >> Adopt structure and its estimators and missions that help teams understand effort patterns without locking design choices.

Typical Discovery outputs :

  • Scoring matrix (relative ranking, not absolute valuation)
  • Constraints register (data gaps, master data quality, authorization concerns)

 Fig: Discovery First Approach: Qualitative Assessment Template

 

Step 5: Build AI Impact Heatmap

Consolidate Findings into an â€œAI Impact Heatmapâ€ Across SAP Processes

Once candidates are scored, the assessment should converge into a single portfolio artifact: an AI impact heatmap - a quadrant-style visualization that positions use cases by value vs feasibility (and optionally overlays adoption readiness).  In SAP engagements, this heatmap becomes a common language between business stakeholders, functional consultants, and enterprise architects because it translates process discussions into prioritization outcomes.

The architectural strength of the heatmap is that it naturally forms a two-speed backlog:

  1. High value / high feasibility : prime candidates for early proof-of-value.
  2. High value / lower feasibility : strategic backlog tied to data/process remediation.

Typical Discovery outputs :

  1. Heatmap with quadrant logic and narrative rationale
  2. â€œDependency notesâ€ for backlog items (data quality, process harmonization)

Fig: Discovery First: Impact Heat Map template 

Step 6: Select Top 3â€“5 Discovery Candidates

Once Winners Use Cases are identified and backlog created, Explicitly End Discovery

The final discovery step is to select a small set of 3â€“5 prioritized candidates that have clear business relevance, process anchoring, and feasible starting points.  The discovery assessment should then stop; solution architecture, tool enablement, and build plans belong to subsequent phases.

SAP Discovery Center can then serve as the â€œbridgeâ€ into execution by providing guided missions and reference assets for moving from decision to adoption in a controlled way.  This ensures the discovery team does not overstep into engineering prematurely while still giving the delivery team a credible launchpad.

 

Fig: Worked Example: â€œFacilitate Invoice Validationâ€ in S/4HANA Finance

What do we do next? 

SAP AI Bestâ€‘Practice Overlay (What to Reference Once Discovery Hands Off)

While discovery remains implementation-agnostic, SAP best practices can (and should) shape the guardrails for what comes next:

  1. Use SAP Discovery Center as the adoption backbone : it is explicitly structured to â€œDiscover, evaluate, and adoptâ€ SAP BTP and SAP Business AI, and it provides missions, reference architectures, and estimators that help teams progress methodically.
  2. Operationalize AI via SAP AI Core + SAP AI Launchpad + AI API : SAP positions AI Core as the execution engine for AI workflows and model serving, AI Launchpad as the central lifecycle management experience, and AI API as a standardized lifecycle interface across runtimes.
  3. Apply SAP BTP AI Best Practices for GenAI patterns : SAP provides repeatable patterns such as secure model access, prompt templating, data masking, content filtering, and vector-based RAG pipelinesâ€”explicitly designed to reduce risk and standardize enterprise implementation.
  4. Adopt Joule where conversational augmentation fits : Joule is positioned as SAPâ€™s copilot for conversational interaction and process assistance across SAP applications, with enterprise readiness and compliance considerations (including GDPR and AI ethics) called out in SAP documentation.
  5. If grounded GenAI is required, use RAG with SAP HANA Cloud Vector Engine : SAP documents vector engine capabilities and the role of vector databases in supporting RAG to improve response quality and mitigate hallucinations, and SAP Architecture Center provides a RAG reference architecture.

Why Discoveryâ€‘First Works in SAP Programs?

A discovery-first assessment is effective because it treats SAP AI as a process portfolio problem, not a tool problem.  By scoping carefully, mapping capabilities to S/4HANA processes, applying consistent heuristics, ranking candidates with lightweight scoring, and consolidating into an impact heatmap, SAP architects create an evidence-based AI backlog that can survive platform changes and implementation debates.  Then, and only then, SAPâ€™s adoption assets - Discovery Center missions, AI Core/Launchpad lifecycle governance, Joule where conversational augmentation fits, and SAP BTP AI Best Practices for secure GenAI design - can be activated to move from discovery to execution with reduced risk.

 

Some quick references that you should go through before such a discovery first exercise:

  • 6 Steps to an AI Assessment in SAP: Discoveryâ€‘First Approach
  • SAP Discovery Centre
  • SAP BTP AI Best Practices overview
  • SAP AI Launchpad official overview
  • SAP Learning (AI Core & Launchpad concepts)
  • Joule official description
  • SAP HANA Cloud Vector Engine guide
  • SAP Architecture Center RAG reference architecture
  • SAP Learning - Digital Discovery Assessment
  • SAP LeanIX Business Capabilities Model

entry.title: Re: editable alv report
entry.content:
I suggest using ABAP 7.5+ syntax:

Instead of this:

DATA: it_ekpo TYPE TABLE OF ekpo,
      it_fcat TYPE slis_t_fieldcat_alv,
      wa_fcat LIKE LINE OF it_fcat.

SELECT * FROM ekpo INTO TABLE it_ekpo WHERE ebeln IN s_ebeln.

CLEAR wa_fcat.
wa_fcat-fieldname = 'EBELN'.
wa_fcat-seltext_l = 'PO Number'.
APPEND wa_fcat TO it_fcat.
" ...more lines

Try this:

SELECT ebeln, ebelp, txz01, menge, netwr
  FROM ekpo
  WHERE ebeln IN @s_ebeln
  INTO TABLE @DATA(it_ekpo).

DATA(it_fcat) = VALUE slis_t_fieldcat_alv(
  ( fieldname = 'EBELN' seltext_l = 'PO Number' )
  ( fieldname = 'TXZ01' seltext_l = 'Text' edit = 'X' )
  ( fieldname = 'MENGE' seltext_l = 'Quantity' edit = 'X' )
).

Or you can use CL_SALV_TABLE :

TRY.
    cl_salv_table=>factory(
      IMPORTING r_salv_table = DATA(lo_alv)
      CHANGING  t_table      = it_ekpo ).

    " Auto-optimize column width
    lo_alv->get_columns( )->set_optimize( abap_true ).

    " Make specific columns editable
    lo_alv->extended_grid_api( )->editable_restricted( )->set_attributes_for_columnname(
      columnname = 'TXZ01'
      all_cells_input_enabled = abap_true ).

    lo_alv->display( ).

  CATCH cx_salv_error INTO DATA(lx_err).
    MESSAGE lx_err->get_text( ) TYPE 'E'.
ENDTRY.

Benefits:

  • No manual field catalog needed (auto-detects structure)
  • Cleaner, more maintainable code
  • Better aligned with S/4HANA standards
If you need complex editable grids with custom validations, CL_SALV_TABLE can be limiting. For those cases, CL_GUI_ALV_GRID is still more flexible.
 
Do you have any specific requirements for the report that are giving you trouble?
